awd_titl_txt: SaTC: STARSS: Small: Combined Side-channel Attacks and Mathematical Foundations of Combined Countermeasures
awd_abstract_narration:
Digital information has become an integral part of our daily lives and there is a growing concern about the security of information. The amount of information that should be kept secure is increasing with the proliferation of high-tech electronics such as smart-phones, tablets, and wearable devices. Accordingly, the number of attacks from malicious parties to obtain the secret information that is stored in a secure (i.e., encrypted) device increases. Side-channel attacks are widely used to extract information from an integrated circuit (IC) or a smart card by observing different leakage sources such as power consumption, timing information, temperature, electromagnetic (EM) emanations, and acoustic waves while loading/executing/storing information. Due to the low cost and potentially non-invasive nature, side-channel attacks pose a serious threat to the security of personal, commercial, and military information. By providing design guidelines against side-channel attacks, our project benefits companies, governments, and individuals in securing the digital information.

This project investigates the power and feasibility of combined side-channel attacks including both physical side-channel attacks (i.e., power, timing, and electromagnetic) and fault injection attacks. Since each attack vector leverages a different leakage mechanism, the countermeasures against different attack vectors may differ significantly. Accordingly, mathematical foundations of combined countermeasures against multiple attack vectors are developed. In this project, the existing resources are utilized as a countermeasure against combined attacks together with dedicated countermeasures to minimize the energy and performance overheads of security. This project provides several opportunities to underrepresented groups and undergraduate students to engage in hardware security research.

por.por_cntn:
Critical information may leak outside of an integrated circuit through various side-channel leakage mechanisms. If analyzed successfully by a malicious attacker, this leakage may pose a serious threat to the security and trustworthiness of the devices that store and process personal, commercial, and military information. Existing countermeasures typically hide/mask/scramble only a specific characteristics of the leaked side-channel signal against a certain attack type. Although a particular countermeasure can be quite effective against a certain side-channel attack, the countermeasures should provide increased resistance against multiple attack types. Accordingly, since combined side-channel attacks can exploit different properties of the leakage, countermeasures should provide increased security against multiple attack types by simultaneously masking/hiding/scrambling distinct properties of the leaked side-channel information.

To achieve this goal, the characteristics of possible side-channel leakage mechanisms have been investigated and the correlation among multiple leakage mechanisms have been explored. The working principles of different distinguishers have been analyzed to better understand their information extraction mechanisms. A preprocessing based framework has been developed to combine multiple distinguishers in a single attack without the need for any profiling or training phase. Different countermeasures have been analyzed and design guidelines have been developed to maximize the security benefit of utilizing multiple countermeasures. We also explore several voltage-regulator based countermeasures which are individually proven superior to traditional techniques. The proposal will potentially change the way security is accomplished against a variety of side-channel attacks by providing a better understanding of both combining different attacks and combining different countermeasures.

This project greatly helped develop a new course "Introduction to Hardware Security" that targets both undergraduate and graduate students to increase the awareness of trustworthy computing. This course has a significant hands-on component which directly benefited from the experiences PI and his group gained from this project. Additionally, throughout the project, several female undergraduate students and students from underrepresented groups had the opportunity to directly work in the PI's research group.

Modified by: Selcuk Kose
